description: Borrowed from Latin interceptum, past participle of intercipi≈ç.

entries.meaning: An interception of a radio broadcast or a telephone call.
(algebraic geometry) The coordinate of the point at which a curve intersects an axis.
examples: Because the horizontal-axis intercept occurs when y=0 and the vertical-axis intercept occurs when x=0, we can find the intercepts algebraically.

entries.meaning: (marketing) A form of market research where consumers are intercepted and interviewed in a retail store or mall.

verbs.description: intercept (third-person singular simple present intercepts, present participle intercepting, simple past and past participle intercepted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To stop, deflect or divert (something in progress or motion).
examples: The police intercepted the package of stolen goods while it was in transit.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive, sports) To gain possession of (the ball) in a ball game

entries.meaning: (transitive, American football) Of a defensive player: to steal a pass thrown by the opposing team, gaining possession of the ball.
(transitive, mathematics) To take or comprehend between.
An aeronautical action in which a fighter approaches a suspicious aircraft to escort it away from a prohibited area, or approaches an enemy aircraft to shoot it down.
